results.title: Doubles basic
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Bill Brind, Colin Low and Bill Mason
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Path of the Paddle”.
Paddling double, the canoeists demonstrate the basic paddling strokes and how to apply them in a variety of combinations to move the canoe at will. Throughout the film the application of each stroke in rapids is shown briefly, with emphasis on the necessity of working as a well-coordinated team.

results.title: Double Trouble
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
One of the earliest works made by Callas using a Fairlight Computer Video Instrument (CVI) processor, a pioneering compositing and special effects system he utilised regularly from the mid 1980s to early 1990s. ‘Double Trouble’ is the first video made by Callas for a large exterior street screen form (in Tokyo). The image appears as though spliced into vertical halves, an array of imagery and characters appearing in double on either side of the division, and moving with alternating motion upwards and downwards. This two-frame animation technique creates two images from one checkerboard stencil which are then reversed, or asynchronously ‘mirrored’, producing an apt metaphor for cultural differences in ‘body language’ between East and West.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

results.title: Double trouble
results.creator_credit: Davidson Films and General Learning Corporation
results.brief_description: Crow and Lion, on an outer space trip, find a cell which begins to divide. The division continues until it approaches a crisis point: the two friends know the spaceship cannot contain the increasing volume of cells. A calculation has to be made to see how many days they can last. The computer read-out demonstrates a number pattern upon which a prediction can be made. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Double trouble
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Geoffrey Bell and Lee Robinson
results.brief_description: Designed to establish cordial relations between Australians and migrants from Europe. Two Australian who criticise the newcomers’ lack of English find themselves in serious difficulties when magically transported to a foreign country.

results.title: Double thread
results.creator_credit: G R Instruction and Mary Field
results.brief_description: How the daily routine is organised for the children’s own needs in a modern well-equipped nursery school in England. Every activity is designed to help the individual child’s development, and to encourage their adjustment to social and group relationships. The “double thread” refers to the inter-relations of home and kindergarten in the growing child’s life.

results.title: Double indemnity (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Joseph Sistrom and Billy Wilder
results.brief_description: Archetypal film noir of the forties, brilliantly filmed and incisively written by Billy Wilder and Raymond Chandler, perfectly capturing the decayed Los Angeles atmosphere of a Chandler novel but using a simpler story and more substantial characters. The hero/villain was almost a new concept. Stars Fred MacMurray, Barbara Stanwyck and Edward G. Robinson. Based on a novel by James M. Cain.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paramount Pictures, Joseph Sistrom and Billy Wilder

results.title: Double indemnity
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Joseph Sistrom and Billy Wilder
results.brief_description: Double Indemnity is possibly the definitive film noir. It features a sharp, literate screenplay with great dialogue (Raymond Chandler worked on the script), a stylish, cool and erotic mise-en-scene by director Billy Wilder, and a stunning performance by Barbara Stanwyck who, in this film, is queen of the femme fatales. She plays a bewitching ice-princess who seduces a crooked insurance agent (Fred MacMurray) into helping her kill her husband to cash in on his insurance policy. This malevolant, spell-binding thriller is based on James M. Cain’s classic pulp novel. Cast also includes Edward G. Robinson.
